Detailed Description

template<typename NativeConditionVar_T, typename Mutex_T>
class sys::ConditionVarInterface< NativeConditionVar_T, Mutex_T >

Interface for any condition variable implementation.

Provide the API for condition variables in this thread wrapper

Definition at line 39 of file ConditionVarInterface.h.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

template<typename NativeConditionVar_T, typename Mutex_T>
sys::ConditionVarInterface< NativeConditionVar_T, Mutex_T >::ConditionVarInterface (  )  [inline]

This constructor means that you are creating the lock that you will use inside of the condition variable. This means that we should delete this ourselves, so the mIsOwner flag is set to true. Its up to the derived class to implement this default constructor. Really, this option is only necessary for CASPR condition variables. It is not the recommended behavior but it may be useful.

Definition at line 52 of file ConditionVarInterface.h.

template<typename NativeConditionVar_T, typename Mutex_T>
sys::ConditionVarInterface< NativeConditionVar_T, Mutex_T >::ConditionVarInterface ( Mutex_T *  theLock,
bool  isOwner = false 
) [inline]

This constructor is the preferred method for creating a new condition variable. It shares a global lock, which must be deleted externally, by default.

Parameters:
theLock This is an existing lock that you wish to use for synchronization purposes
isOwner This defaults to false, which means that your condition variable is not responsible for the deletion of the mutex (in other words, you must delete the mutex explicitly. If you set this parameter to true, you may actually be sharing a lock, but this class will STILL delete it.

Definition at line 101 of file ConditionVarInterface.h.

template<typename NativeConditionVar_T, typename Mutex_T>
NativeConditionVar_T& sys::ConditionVarInterface< NativeConditionVar_T, Mutex_T >::getNative (  )  [inline]

Returns the native type. You probably should not use this unless you have specific constraints on which package you use Use of this function may defeat the purpose of these classes: to provide thread implementation in an abstract interface.

Definition at line 142 of file ConditionVarInterface.h.

Return the type name. This function is essentially free, because it is static RTTI due to its template implementation

template<typename NativeConditionVar_T, typename Mutex_T>
virtual bool sys::ConditionVarInterface< NativeConditionVar_T, Mutex_T >::wait ( double  timeout  )  [pure virtual]

Wait for on a signal for a time interval. This should eventually have a class TimeInterval as the second argument, which takes any time interval as a right-hand-side

Parameters:
timeout How long to wait. This is only temporarily a double
Todo:
Create a TimeInterval class, and use it as parameter
Returns:
true upon success

Implemented in sys::ConditionVarIrix, sys::ConditionVarNSPR, sys::ConditionVarPosix, sys::ConditionVarSolaris, and sys::ConditionVarWin32.
